article:
'Absolute liability' is a standard of legal liability found in tort and criminal
law of various legal jurisdictions.

To be convicted of an ordinary crime, in certain jurisdictions, a person must
not only have committed a criminal action, but also have had a deliberate
intention or guilty mind (mens rea). In a crime of [[strict liability
(criminal)]] or absolute liability, a person could be guilty even if there was
no intention to commit a crime. The difference between strict and absolute
liability is whether the defence of a mistake of fact is available: in a crime
of absolute liability, a mistake of fact is not a defence.
